nodes.body:
Comparative constructions are formed by taking the short form of an adjective and adding the suffix པ་. The term being compared is followed by ལས་. The markers ལས་ and ནས་ are the two forms of the ablative that are used in Literary Tibetan, but in the spoken language it is only ནས་ that denotes the ablative, whereas ལས་ is reserved for comparative constructions.

  • འདི་ལས་མང་ང་(མང་བ་)འདུག “There is more than that.”
  • ཆང་སྦི་རག་ལས་ཞིམ་པ། “Chang is better than beer.”
  • དེབ་དེ་འདི་ལས་ཡག་ག (ཡག་པ།) “That book is better than this one.”
  • གཡག་མཛོ་ལས་ཆེ་བ་འདུག་གས། “Are yaks bigger than dzo?”
  • གཡག་མཛོ་ལས་ཆེ་བ། “Yaks are bigger than dzo!”

The auxiliary འདུག་ is optional in declarative sentences, whereas it is obligatory in negative and interrogative sentences.

Note that the position of the item being compared is not fixed; it may also come first:

  • སྦི་རག་ལས་ཆང་ཞིམ་པ། “Compared with beer, chang is better.”

When the adjective is an attribute of the subject, another construction is also commonly used: the short form of the adjective is followed by the auxiliary གི་རེད།.

  • འདི་ལས་མང་གི་རེད། “There is more than this.”
  • ཆང་སྦི་རག་ལས་ཞིམ་གྱི་རེད། “Chang is better than beer.”
  • གཡག་མཛོ་ལས་ཆེ་གི་རེད། “Yaks are bigger than dzo.”
  • ལྷ་ས་པེ་ཅིང་ལས་བསིལ་གི་རེད། “It’s colder in Lhasa than in Beijing.”
  • སྣ་ལོ་བཞོན་ན་ཡག་གི་རེད། “It’s better to ride a nalo (gentle, hornless yak).”
  • གནམ་གྲུའི་ནང་ལ་བཏང་ན་གོང་ཆེ་གི་མ་རེད་པས། “Won’t it cost more to send it by air?”

Tibetan has no special constructions for marking comparatives of inferiority. “Less than” is expressed simply reversing the order of comparison or by using an opposite adjective.

For example, to translate the expression “He is less poor than I am,” Tibetan would use these constructions, based on context:

  • ང་ཁོང་ལས་སྐྱོ་གི་རེད། “I’m poorer than him.”
  • ཁོང་ང་ལས་ཕྱུག་གི་རེད། “He’s richer than me.”
  • ཁོང་ང་ལས་སྐྱོ་བ་ཡོད་མ་རེད། “He isn’t poorer than me.”
nodes.title: About The Comparative Suffix པ་, and Other Comparative Constructions
